Let X and Y be topological spaces, and let f:X -> Y be a continuous function. Let {x_n} be a sequence in X that converges to a point x in X. 

Using the definition of continuity in topology, prove that the sequence {f(x_n)} converges to f(x) in Y.
message_2:
To prove that the sequence {f(x_n)} converges to f(x) in Y, we need to show that for every open neighborhood V of f(x) in Y, there exists a positive integer N such that for all n ≥ N, f(x_n) ∈ V.

Since f is continuous, by the definition of continuity in topology, for every open neighborhood V of f(x) in Y, f^(-1)(V) is an open set in X containing x. Since {x_n} converges to x in X, there exists a positive integer N such that for all n ≥ N, x_n ∈ f^(-1)(V). 

Now, since x_n ∈ f^(-1)(V), this means that f(x_n) ∈ V for all n ≥ N. Thus, the sequence {f(x_n)} converges to f(x) in Y.

This completes the proof.
